docs.lead_paragraph: Seeking to better understand the origins of breast cancer, researchers have begun to look as far back as the womb to identify prenatal factors and childhood experiences, including birth weight, diet and exercise patterns, that may affect a woman's risk of developing breast cancer. Though the data are preliminary, the relationships complex and the conclusions tentative, the emerging findings may help to explain long-suspected influences on breast cancer risk like early puberty, the age of a woman at the end of her first full-term pregnancy and the amount of fat and calories in her diet.

headline.main: Risks For Cancer Can Start In Womb

docs.abstract: Researchers are looking as far back as the womb to identify prenatal factors and childhood experiences, including birth weight, diet and exercise patterns, that may affect woman's risk of developing breast cancer; emerging findings may help to explain long-suspected influences on breast cancer risk like early puberty, age of woman at end of her first full-term pregnancy and amount of fat and calories in her diet (M)
